docs.lead_paragraph: THERE'S a power struggle under way in many households between parents and nannies, and the nannies seem to be gaining the upper hand. You've heard about parents who install videocams so they can spy on the baby sitter? Well, nannies are beginning to return the scrutiny. Just check out the chat rooms proliferating on the Internet, where nannies exchange juicy anecdotes about dysfunctional parents and their spoiled offspring. ''What good am I to these kids when I'm angry and frustrated?'' one nanny recently asked her peers.
docs.abstract: Nannies are becoming much more powerful figure in many households and are operating with more clout amid fierce competition among moms who want on-call care and are willing to pay top dollar and offer lucrative perks to get it; photo; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Five workers who sprayed pesticides for a city contractor last summer to kill mosquitoes carrying the West Nile virus have filed a complaint with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, contending that improper training and prolonged exposure to the chemicals made them sick. In an affidavit, the men detailed how they were repeatedly saturated with the pesticide Anvil during their nightly spraying shifts, while driving or riding without protective clothing on the backs of trucks. The former sprayers and truck drivers also said they handled and loaded pesticides without training or supervision, contrary to state and federal regulations. Their claims were first reported yesterday by The Daily News.

headline.main: Workers Say Chemicals Used in Mosquito Spraying Made Them Ill

docs.abstract: Five workers who sprayed pesticides for city contractor last summer to kill mosquitoes carrying West Nile virus file complaint with Occupational Safety and Health Administration, contending that improper training and prolonged exposure to chemicals made them sick; spokesman for contractor, Clarke Mosquito Control Products, denies any negligence or wrongdoing; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After Nassau County lost tens of millions of dollars by switching health insurance providers in 1997, one of the many public officials singled out for criticism was Owen B. Walsh, who was then the county attorney. An investigation of the debacle commissioned by the County Legislature found last summer that Mr. Walsh had ''failed to fulfill his responsibilities'' and noted that he had not alerted other officials to potential problems with the deal. It went on to say that instead of conducting his own legal research, Mr. Walsh had relied on opinions from lawyers working for the company seeking the contract. He even let them draft the contract, it said.

headline.main: Contract To Ex-Official Stirs Protest In Nassau

docs.abstract: Democrats in Nassau County Legislature express shock at disclosure that Owen B Walsh, who resigned as county attorney in 1999 after disclosure that Nassau County lost tens of millions of dollars by switching health insurance providers in 1997, has been given $15,000 contract as consultant to help county select new reirement savings plan for its workers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A three-year investigation of price manipulation by the nation's drug companies scored its first important victory today when the Bayer Corporation agreed to cooperate with prosecutors and to pay $14 million in restitution to the federal government and the states. Under an agreement with the Justice Department and 45 states, Bayer settled charges that it had caused doctors and hospitals to submit inflated claims for prescription drugs used by Medicaid patients.

headline.main: Bayer to Pay $14 Million to Settle Charges of Causing Inflated Medicaid Claims

docs.abstract: Bayer Corp agrees to pay $14 million in restitution to federal government and 45 states to settle charges that it caused doctors and hospitals to submit inflated claims for prescription drugs used by Medicaid patients; will cooperate with law enforcement authorities investigating similar pricing practices of 20 other drug companies (M)
docs.snippet: A three-year investigation of price manipulation by the nation's drug companies scored its first important victory today when the Bayer Corporation agreed to cooperate with prosecutors and to pay $14 million in restitution to the federal government...

docs.lead_paragraph: While drug lords and organized-crime bosses may have been the more high-profile targets of the Department of Justice in recent years, among the most hotly pursued culprits have been those who commit health care fraud. Emboldened by new laws and flush with money for lawyers and investigators, United States attorneys throughout the country more than quadrupled the rate of convictions for criminal health care fraud from 1992 to 1999, from one a week to roughly one a weekday, according to Justice Department figures. The new resources were critical to the effort because health care fraud cases are expensive and difficult to pursue.

headline.main: Justice Dept. Finds Success Chasing Health Care Fraud

docs.abstract: Justice Department statistics show most hotly pursued criminals in recent years have been those who commit health-care fraud; finds US attorneys nationwide, emboldened by new laws and flush with funds for lawyers and investigators, more than quadrupled rate of convictions for criminal health care fraud from 1992 to 1999 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is not exactly a soft landing for Clinton loyalists in the federal government, but if they could not take time out in their last frenetic days at work, today they can apply for unemployment insurance. Over the last few weeks, the District of Columbia Office of Employment Services went from federal department to department briefing 1,700 appointees on the worst-case option. They were told that to be eligible, they must be unemployed ''through no fault of your own.''
docs.abstract: Thousands who worked in Clinton administration are engaged in job search, with many are collecting unemployment insurance (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Some of the welfare-to-work policies adopted by states in recent years benefit children in low-income families by improving their school performance, researchers said today. Requiring single mothers to work as a condition of receiving cash assistance did not hurt their children, as many people had feared, the study said. When the work requirements, combined with other policies intended to reward work, led to an increase in family income, the children actually did better in school than youngsters in similar poor families that simply received cash assistance under the old welfare rules.

headline.main: Gains Reported for Children of Welfare-to-Work Families

docs.abstract: New study by nonprofit Manpower Demonstration Research Corp finds some of welfare-to-work policies adopted by states in recent years benefit children in low-income families by improving their school performance; finds when work requirements combined with other policies intended to reward work led to increase in family income, children actually did better in school than youngsters in similar poor families that simply received cash assistance under old welfare rules; its other findings discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Yvonne Reed-Bennett, 33, has had it with hospitals. ''Waking up in straitjackets, with I.V.'s hanging from my arm,'' she said, ''I don't do that no more.'' Ms. Reed-Bennett has a rare disorder that causes frequent seizures, usually more than one a week. ''Sometimes I'll hear the things that are going on around me and I can't do anything about it,'' she said. ''Sometimes I'm just out cold. Those are the ones the doctors really worry about.''

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Pounded by Illness, Lifted by Kindness

docs.abstract: Children's Aid Society, supported by New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, assists mother of three in enrolling her children for health insurance, and buys winter clothing for them; photo (M)
